revision.text:
{{for|the British comedian|Stu Francis}} {{Use Canadian English|date=October 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Stewart Francis | image = | imagesize = 200 px | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1959/1960 | birth_place = [[Toronto, Ontario]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | medium = Stand-up, television | nationality = Canadian | active = | genre = [[Deadpan]], [[Wit]] | subject = [[One-liner joke|One liners]] | influences = | influenced = | spouse = | domesticpartner = | notable_work = ''[[You Bet Your Ass]]'' | signature = | website = {{url|stewartfrancis.com}} | footnotes = }}
'''Stewart Francis''' is a Canadian comedian, actor and writer. In addition to his work in Canada and the US, he frequently tours in the UK and appears on British television. Both of Francis' parents are British. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.berwick-advertiser.co.uk/leisure/Comedian-Stewart-Francis-is-pedalling.6304254.jp |title=Comedian Stewart Francis is pedalling the laughs – Leisure |publisher=Berwick Advertiser |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=2012-08-21}}</ref>
Francis was born in Saint Joseph’s Health Centre in Toronto, and attended Eatonville Junior School, in Etobicoke. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalpost.com/news/canada/meet-stewart-francis-canadas-king-of-the-one-liners/amp |title=Meet Stewart Francis, Canada’s King of One Liners |date=28 August 2012 |accessdate=2018-01-20}} </ref>
==Career==
===Stand-up=== Francis delivers a [[deadpan]] performance with many [[One-liner joke|one-liner]]s.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Stewart Francis | date= June 2007 | publisher= chortle.co.uk | url =http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/s/205/stewart_francis/review/ | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2008-09-16 | language = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first= Emma | last= Lennox | coauthors= | title=Stewart Francis: 148 People Can't Be Wrong 7 Mar, Blackfriars Basement | date= 1 April 2008 | publisher= theskinny.co.uk | url =http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/42218-stewart-francis-148-people-cant-be-wrong-7-mar-blackfriars-basement | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2008-09-16 | language = }}</ref>
Francis has headlined all over North America and the United Kingdom. He has also performed in numerous venues worldwide, including Hong Kong, South Africa, and throughout Europe.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Stewart Francis | date= | publisher= comedycv.co.uk | url =http://www.comedycv.co.uk/stewartfrancis/index.htm | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2008-09-16 | language = }}</ref> On 6 June 2009 he performed on the [[Edinburgh]] section of ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]''. Francis was the support act for [[Ricky Gervais]] on his Science tour,<ref>{{cite news|title=Stewart Francis: on touring|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/comedy/8120522/Stewart-Francis-on-touring.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 November 2010|accessdate=6 September 2011}}</ref> performing in such places as [[Portsmouth Guildhall]], [[New Theatre, Oxford]], [[Brighton Centre]] and the [[The O2 (Dublin)|O2 Arena]] in Dublin in late 2009 and early 2010. He has also made 12 appearances on popular British panel show ''[[Mock the Week]]''. He appeared on ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'' on 9 December 2010 and 14 December 2012. In 2012 he won the annual award for the funniest joke of the [[Edinburgh Fringe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-19316443 |title=BBC News – Stewart Francis's Posh and Becks joke Fringe 'funniest' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-08-21}}</ref>
===Acting=== Stewart starred as a series regular on ''[[An American in Canada]]'' and also acted in ''[[Kevin Hill]]''. In 2007, he appeared in an episode of the [[BBC]] sitcom ''[[Not Going Out]]'' as Hillary Allison. (The producers said in an interview that he had been considered for the part of recurring character Guy, but rejected because he was too young and given this role instead.) He also made a brief appearance in ''[[The Omid Djalili Show]]''.
===Writing=== Stewart has written for ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'', ''[[The Gemini Awards]]'' and ''[[Puppets Who Kill]]'', as well as having his work published in ''[[The Hockey News]]''.
===Television work=== In the US he was a regular guest on ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]'' and he was the host of trivia game show ''[[You Bet Your Ass]]''. In the UK, his TV appearances include ''[[The Comedy Store]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[8 out of 10 Cats]]'', ''The Big Stage'', ''For One Night Only'' and ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]''. After his first appearance on ''Mock the Week'' as an almost unknown, he was so successful he was asked back three more times in the series that followed. In 2010 Stewart appeared in a special [[Children in Need]] episode of ''[[Mastermind (TV series)|Mastermind]]'' where his specialist subject was the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]].
==Stand-up DVDs== * ''Live – Tour de Francis'' (22 November 2010) * ''Live: Outstanding in His Field'' (26 November 2012) * ''Pun Gent'' (28 November 2016)
